content: How can I help you today?

Well, honestly, I’ve been feeling really stressed about work lately. I’m worried about getting fired with all the layoffs happening everywhere, and it’s been keeping me up at night. I just can’t seem to turn my brain off once my head hits the pillow, and it’s wearing me down. My partner suggested I talk to someone, so here I am.

Thank you for sharing that. It sounds like the stress about work and the fear of layoffs have been weighing heavily on you, even affecting your sleep. It’s understandable why you’d feel this way, especially with everything going on around you. It’s great that you’re taking a step to talk about it. How do you feel this stress has been impacting other parts of your life?

Honestly, it feels like it’s bleeding into everything. I’m more irritable with my partner and kids, and I feel like I can’t fully focus on them because my mind is always racing. I’m constantly thinking about all the "what ifs" at work and how I'd support my family if the worst happens. It’s hard to shake this feeling of anxiety no matter what I try.

Thank you for opening up about that. It sounds like the stress is taking a toll not just on you, but also on your relationships and your ability to be present with your loved ones. You’re carrying a lot, and it’s clear that supporting your family is really important to you. How have you been trying to cope with these feelings so far?

I haven't really been doing much to cope, to be honest. Sometimes I just try to distract myself with TV or scrolling on my phone, but it doesn’t really help. I’ve tried talking to my partner a bit, but I don’t want to worry them too much since they already have enough on their plate. Mostly, I feel stuck in this cycle of overthinking.

It sounds like you’ve been trying some ways to manage the stress, even if they haven’t been as effective as you’d hoped. It’s understandable that you don’t want to add to your partner’s worries, but you’re also navigating a lot on your own, which can feel overwhelming. What do you think might help break that cycle of overthinking, even just a little?

I honestly don’t know what would help at this point. I’ve been stuck in my own head for so long that it feels impossible to figure out how to quiet it down. I guess maybe if I could find a way to stop replaying all these "what if" scenarios in my mind, that might help, but I’m not sure how to do that.

It can feel exhausting being stuck in that loop of "what if" thoughts, and wanting to quiet them shows that you’re already recognizing what could bring some relief. That’s an important step. It might be worth exploring ways to ground yourself in the present moment or redirect your thoughts when those scenarios start playing in your mind. Have you ever had moments where you’ve felt more calm or clear-headed recently, even if only briefly?

Not really, to be honest. It’s like whenever I get a quiet moment, all those worries just flood back in. Maybe when I'm playing with my kids or watching them laugh, I can forget for a few minutes, but it’s short-lived. It feels like my mind just keeps pulling me back into all the stress.

It’s meaningful that spending time with your kids and seeing their joy brings you at least a brief escape from the stress. Even if it’s short-lived, it shows that there are moments where you can feel more present. Maybe leaning more into those moments or finding similar activities that bring that sense of connection or calm could help. What do you think about that?

It’s meaningful that spending time with your kids and seeing their joy brings you at least a brief escape from the stress. Even if it’s short-lived, it shows that there are moments where you can feel more present. Maybe leaning more into those moments or finding similar activities that bring that sense of connection or calm could help. What do you think about that?

It’s meaningful that spending time with your kids and seeing their joy brings you at least a brief escape from the stress. Even if it’s short-lived, it shows that there are moments where you can feel more present. Maybe leaning more into those moments or finding similar activities that bring that sense of connection or calm could help. What do you think about that?

Yeah, I think that could help. It’s just hard because my mind always seems to find its way back to the stress. But maybe if I make more of an effort to focus on those little moments, it could give me a break from all the worrying. It’s worth a shot, I guess.

Recognizing those moments as breaks and making an effort to focus on them is a thoughtful step. It’s not easy to redirect your mind when the stress feels so persistent, but even small shifts can add up over time. It’s encouraging that you’re willing to give it a try. What kind of moments or activities do you think you could intentionally focus on, even if it’s just for a little while?

Recognizing those moments as breaks and making an effort to focus on them is a thoughtful step. It’s not easy to redirect your mind when the stress feels so persistent, but even small shifts can add up over time. It’s encouraging that you’re willing to give it a try. What kind of moments or activities do you think you could intentionally focus on, even if it’s just for a little while?

You’ve mentioned how playing with your kids and spending time with your family brings some joy and relief, even if briefly. That could be a meaningful place to start—intentionally carving out moments where you can fully immerse in their laughter or a shared activity. Have you thought about whether there’s anything else, like hobbies or relaxation techniques, that might give you something to focus on and shift your mind away from the stress?

I think spending more time playing with my kids could be a good start. They really help me forget about everything when I’m with them. Maybe even taking walks with my family or doing something active together would help me stay in the moment.

Spending more time with your kids and family, especially through something active like walks, sounds like a positive way to stay present and connect. That time together could offer not only moments of joy but also a bit of relief from those racing thoughts. How do you feel about giving that a try and seeing how it feels?

Spending more time with your kids and engaging in activities like walks sounds like a great way to connect and be present. It could also give your mind some space away from the stress. Starting small and seeing how it feels is definitely a good approach. Are there particular activities you think your kids would enjoy that might help you all bond and unwind?

It’s wonderful to hear that you’re considering spending more time with your kids through activities like walks or bonding moments—they can really make a difference. Starting small and seeing how it feels is definitely a good approach. Are there particular activities you think your kids would enjoy that might help you all bond and unwind?
